Authors with affiliations: Zykov, A.M., All-Russia Thermal Engineering Institute, 14/23 Avtozavodskaya Str., 109280, Moscow, Russian Federation; Kolchin, K.I., All-Russia Thermal Engineering Institute, 14/23 Avtozavodskaya Str., 109280, Moscow, Russian Federation; Tumanovsky, A.G., All-Russia Thermal Engineering Institute, 14/23 Avtozavodskaya Str., 109280, Moscow, Russian Federation; Jozewicz, W., ARCADIS G and M, Inc., 4915 Prospectus Drive, Durham, NC 27713, United States
Abstract: Electrostatic precipitators (ESP) are broadly applied at solid coal-fired thermal power plants (TPPs) throughout the power industry in Russia and in other countries of the Newly Independent States (NIS). Approximately two-thirds of these ESPs are of older design and with operational efficiencies in the range of 85-95 percent. Typical efficiency of newer ESPs installed in the last 10-15 years is in the range of 96-99 percent. On average, the actual cleaning efficiency of ESPs installed in NIS power plants is 96 percent. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has initiated a joint project with the All-Russia Thermal Engineering Institute (VTI) with the objective of improving ESPs at selected TPPs in the NIS and thereby, assisting with particulate matter (PM) emission reductions. Initially in the project, an ESP diagnostic tool was transferred to VTI and a hands-on training was conducted by VTI experts for ESP designers, operators, and others concerned with air pollution control in the NIS. The tool used during the training was ESPVI 4.0 computer model for Windows, developed over a number of years and upgraded for the needs of the project in Russia under the sponsorship of the EPA. Currently, the project team is finalizing assistance agreements with selected power plants in Russia, Kazakhstan, and Ukraine. Upgrade activities have already been initiated at selected TPPs as their in-kind contributions. This paper describes NIS TPPs and associated ESPs, results of computer simulations of their ESPs, recommended upgrades, and predicted PM emission reduction benefits resulting from implementation of these upgrades. The on-going ESP upgrade activities at two TPPs in Russia are also discussed in the paper.

Abstract: The European Union (EU) and many of its member states will fail to meet their Kyoto Protocol targets for limiting greenhouse gas emissions on the basis of the domestic policies and measures implemented or planned so far. Most of the central and eastern European countries that plan to join the EU are however on track to meet the Kyoto targets.

Title: Commission proposes transitional periods for accession countries
Source title: Euroheat and Power (English Edition)
Abstract: The European Commission presented a proposal to amend the Energy Tax Directive, to allow European Union (EU) accession countries temporarily to apply excise duty exemptions or lower rates of duty than the EU-wide minimum rates normally required on all energy products. The varying arrangements proposed cover all the accession countries except Cyprus. The proposal would ensure that the principles which governed the granting of transitional periods for existing member states would apply equally to the accession member states. It will allow member states to offer companies tax incentives in return for specific undertakings to reduce emissions.

Title: A farewell broad(side)?
Source title: Electrical World
Abstract: The views of Paul Broad, chief executive of Energy Australia, on a new base load power station in NSW or Victoria, Australia are discussed. According to him, a decision on the power station in either of the region will have to be made soon as it will take about seven years to build. Moreover, the new station on the eastern seaboard would either be using Victorian brown or NSW black coal as a fuel source. The country desperately needs a national approach advocating an emissions trading type scheme.

Title: Evolving EPA VOC test methods (sponsored by P & PQ)
Source title: 2004 TAPPI Paper Summit - Spring Technical and International Environmental Conference
Abstract: Three published EPA test methods are most commonly used to quantify volatile compound (VOC) emissions: EPA Methods 18, 25, and 25a. Certain recent EPA enforcement initiative targeting PSD/NSR permitting and associated control technology determinations have raised some questions regarding the published VOC test methods. MACT rules, Title V permitting, and continuing uncertainty regarding routine repair and maintenance, may increase the need for VOC testing to determine applicability and permitting requirements. Future regional policy efforts to achieve attainment of the 8-hour ozone standard and address PM2.5 will result in additional emission reduction measures targeting VOC/s. An evolving policy discussion highlights potential issues around the definition of VOC and the application of the available published test methods. Further complexity arises from EPA efforts focused around other testing approaches such as the Midwest Scaling Protocol. This session will briefly review certain VOC regulatory requirements, published VOC test methods, questions that have been raised regarding the available VOC test methods, a review of the latest version of the Midwest Scaling Protocol, and a brief review of the positions EPA has taken in recent enforcement proceedings regarding VOC's.
Index Keywords: Computational complexity; Computer systems; Maintenance; Network protocols; Public policy; Emission reduction; Midwest Scaling Protocol; Regional policy; Routine repair and maintenance; Volatile organic compounds; Maintenance; Voc

Authors: Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD)
Title: Can cars come clean?: Strategies for low-emission vehicles
Source title: Can Cars Come Clean?: Strategies for Low-emission Vehicles
Authors with affiliations: Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD)
Abstract: This report identifies policy options and makes recommendations on market-oriented actions to promote the purchase of the most environmentally friendly vehicles. It assesses the impact of a wider use of low-emission vehicles, drawing on experience to date, research results and the responses to a survey from 18 OECD countries. The main section - Policy Options - presents in non-technical language, the current and expected performance of conventional and innovative technologies. It is for policy makers worldwide, economists and the casual reader. © OECD 2004.
